{{About|the West End theatre in London}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox Theatre |name = Garrick Theatre |image = HE1217927 Garrick Theatre.jpg |caption = Garrick Theatre in 2017 |address = [[Charing Cross Road]] |city = [[London]], [[WC postcode area|WC2]] |country = United Kingdom |designation = [[listed building|Grade II*]] |publictransit = {{rint|london|underground}} {{lus|Charing Cross}}; {{lus|Leicester Square}}
{{rint|gb|Rail}} {{rws|Charing Cross}} |coordinates = {{coord|51.509722|-0.128056|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |architect = [[Walter Emden]], with [[Charles J. Phipps|C. J. Phipps]] |owner = Nimax Theatres |capacity = 718{{cite web | url=http://www.nimaxtheatres.com/garrick-theatre/ | title=Garrick Theatre | publisher=nimaxtheatres.com | accessdate=2 July 2013}} on 3 levels (currently)
800 on 4 levels (originally) |type = [[West End theatre]] |opened = {{Start date and age|1889|04|24|df=yes}} |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = ''[[Don Quixote]]'' |currentuse = |website = http://www.nimaxtheatres.com/garrick-theatre/ }} The '''Garrick Theatre''' is a [[West End theatre]], located on [[Charing Cross Road]], in the [[City of Westminster]], named after the stage actor [[David Garrick]].Holland, Peter. "David Garrick", in Banham, Martin (ed.) ''The Cambridge Guide to Theatre'', London, Cambridge University Press (1995), pp. 411–412 It opened in 1889 with ''The Profligate'', a play by [[Arthur Wing Pinero]], and another Pinero play, ''[[The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith]]'', was an early success at the theatre. In its early years, the Garrick appears to have specialised in the performance of [[melodrama]]. The theatre later became associated with comedies, including ''[[No Sex Please, We're British]]'', which played for four years from 1982 to 1986. ==History== There was previously another theatre that was sometimes called the [[Garrick Theatre (Leman St)|Garrick]] in London, on Leman Street, opened in 1831 and demolished in 1881.Allingham, Philip V. [http://www.victorianweb.org/mt/theaters/pva234.html "Theatres in Victorian London"], The Victorian Web, 29 November 2015 The new Garrick Theatre was financed in 1889 by the playwright [[W. S. Gilbert]], the author of over 75 plays, including the [[Gilbert and Sullivan]] [[comic opera]]s. It was designed by [[Walter Emden]], with [[Charles J. Phipps|C. J. Phipps]] brought in as a consultant to help with the planning on the difficult site after an underground river was discovered in the excavation. Originally the theatre had 800 seats on four levels, but the gallery (top) level has since been closed and the [[seating capacity]] reduced to 656. The theatre's first manager was Gilbert's friend [[John Hare (actor)|John Hare]].[http://garrick.official-theatre.co.uk/london/history "Garrick Theatre – Theatre history"], Best of Theatre, accessed 24 December 2015 The first play at the theatre, ''The Profligate'', by [[Arthur Wing Pinero]] and starring Hare, opened on 24 April 1889. [[Sydney Grundy]]'s long-running French-style comedy ''A Pair of Spectacles'' opened here in February 1890. [[Mrs Patrick Campbell]] starred five years later in Pinero's ''[[The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith]]''. Afterwards, the theatre suffered a short period of decline until it was leased by [[Arthur Bourchier]] for six years, whose wife, [[Violet Vanbrugh]], starred in a series of successful productions ranging from farce to [[Shakespeare]].Littlewood, S. R. [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36623 "Vanbrugh, Dame Irene (1872–1949)",] ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004; online edition, January 2011, accessed 7 Jan 2011 {{subscription}} In 1900, the theatre hosted [[J. M. Barrie]]'s ''The Wedding Guest''. [[Rutland Barrington]] presented several stage works at the Garrick, including his popular "fairy play" called ''Water Babies'' in 1902, based on [[Charles Kingsley]]'s [[The Water-Babies, A Fairy Tale for a Land Baby|book]], with music by [[Alfred Cellier]], among others. The only piece actually premiered by W. S. Gilbert here was ''[[Harlequin and the Fairy's Dilemma]]'' (retitled ''The Fairy's Dilemma'' after a few days), a "Domestic Pantomime" (1904). In 1921, [[Basil Rathbone]] played Dr. Lawson in ''The Edge o' Beyond'' at the Garrick, and the following year Sir [[Seymour Hicks]] appeared in his own play, ''The Man in Dress Clothes''. In 1925 [[Henry Daniell]] played there as Jack Race in ''Cobra'' and appeared there again as Paul Cortot in ''Marriage by Purchase'' in March 1932. A proposed redevelopment of [[Covent Garden]] by the [[Greater London Council|GLC]] in 1968 saw the theatre under threat, together with the nearby [[Vaudeville Theatre|Vaudeville]], [[Adelphi Theatre|Adelphi]], [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum]] and [[Duchess Theatre|Duchess theatre]]s. An active campaign by [[British Actors' Equity Association|Equity]], the [[Musicians' Union (UK)|Musicians' Union]], and theatre owners under the auspices of the ''Save London Theatres Campaign'' led to the abandonment of the scheme.[http://www.vaudevilletheatre.org.uk/history.html "Theatre History"], Vaudeville Theatre, accessed 12 June 2013 The gold-leaf auditorium was restored in 1986 by the stage designer [[Carl Toms]], and in 1997 the front façade was renovated. The theatre has mostly been associated with comedies or comedy-dramas. More recent productions are listed below and include ''[[No Sex Please, We're British]]'' (1982), which played for four years at the theatre before transferring to the [[Duchess Theatre]] in 1986. In 1995, the [[Royal National Theatre]]'s multi-award-winning production of [[J. B. Priestley]]'s ''[[An Inspector Calls]]'' opened here, having played successful seasons at the Royal National Theatre's Lyttelton and Olivier theatres as well as the [[Aldwych Theatre]] and a season on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. In 1986, the Garrick was acquired by the [[Moss Empires|Stoll Moss Group]], and in 2000 it became a ''Really Useful Theatre'' when [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s [[Really Useful Group]] and [[Bridgepoint Capital]] purchased Stoll Moss Theatres Ltd. In October 2005, [[Nica Burns]] and Max Weitzenhoffer purchased the Garrick Theatre, and it became one of five playhouses operating under their company name of [[Nimax Theatres]] Ltd, alongside the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]], [[Apollo Theatre]], [[Vaudeville Theatre]] and [[Duchess Theatre]]. The interior retains many of its original features, and was [[listed building|Grade II* listed]] by [[English Heritage]] in September 1960.[http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?pid=2&id=209097 English Heritage listing details], accessed 28 April 2007 ==Notable productions== *1890 – ''A Pair of Spectacles'' by [[Sydney Grundy]] *1895 – ''[[The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith]]'', starring [[Mrs Patrick Campbell]] *1902 – ''Water Babies'', an adaptation by [[Rutland Barrington]] of [[Charles Kingsley]]'s [[The Water-Babies, A Fairy Tale for a Land Baby|novel]], with music by [[Alfred Cellier]] and others. *1947 – [[Laurence Olivier]] directed [[Jack Buchanan]] in ''Born Yesterday'' [[File:GarrickTheatre.png|thumb|Garrick Theatre in 2007]] *1955 – ''[[La Plume de Ma Tante]]'' ran to 1957 *1960 – [[Lionel Bart]]'s ''[[Fings Ain't Wot They Used T'Be]]'' began a two-year run with [[Miriam Karlin]] *1967 – [[Brian Rix]] presented and appeared in ''Stand By Your Bedouin'', the first in several seasons of farces, including ''Uproar in the House'' and ''Let Sleeping Wives Lie'' *1971 – The last of these farces was ''[[Don't Just Lie There, Say Something!]]'' *1972 – [[Anthony Shaffer (writer)|Anthony Shaffer's]] ''[[Sleuth (play)|Sleuth]]'' transferred *1977 – ''[[Side By Side By Sondheim]]'' transferred and was a continuing success. *1978 – [[Ira Levin]]'s thriller ''[[Deathtrap (play)|Deathtrap]]'' began a long run until 1981 *1982 – ''[[No Sex Please, We're British]]'' transferred from the [[Novello Theatre|Strand Theatre]] and remained until 1986 *1995 – ''[[An Inspector Calls]]'' began its second prolonged West End season *2002 – ''[[This is Our Youth]]'' played two seasons *2009 – ''[[A Little Night Music]]'' played until 2011 *2011 – ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]'' transferred from the [[Cambridge Theatre]]; closed in 2012 after 15 years in the West End *2013 – ''[[Rock of Ages (musical)|Rock of Ages]]'' transferred from the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] for its last year in the West End[https://www.londontheatredirect.com/venue/32/Garrick-Theatre.aspx The Garrick Theatre, London], London Theatre Direct, accessed 25 January 2017 *2014 – ''[[Let It Be (musical)|Let it Be]]'' transferred from the Savoy Theatre; played briefly in 2014 and through most of 2015 *2015 – Kenneth Branagh Theatre Company presented several plays through 2016 *2017 – ''[[Young Frankenstein (musical)|Young Frankenstein]]'' ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * ''Guide to British Theatres 1750–1950'', John Earl and Michael Sell pp. 111 (Theatres Trust, 2000) {{ISBN|0-7136-5688-3}} * ''Who's Who in the Theatre'', edited by John Parker, tenth edition, revised, London, 1947, pps: 477–478 and 1184. ==External links== {{Commons category|Garrick Theatre, Westminster}} * [http://www.nimaxtheatres.com/nimax/garrick Official Garrick Theatre Website] * [http://www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/GarrickTheatre.htm Article on Garrick Theatre] * [http://www.victorianweb.org/mt/theaters/pva234.html Information about the Garrick and other Victorian theatres] {{Theatres in London}} {{Nimax}} [[Category:West End theatres]] [[Category:Theatres in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in the City of Westminster]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1889]] [[Category:Charles J. Phipps buildings]] [[Category:Performance art venues]] [[Category:Charing Cross Road]] [[Category:Memorials to David Garrick]]

[[Image:Silver cauldron.jpg|thumb|right|The Gundestrup Cauldron; exterior plates '''b, g, e''']] {{Location map | Denmark | relief = yes | width = 300 | caption = Discovery site in Denmark | lat_deg =56.82 | lon_deg =9.55 | label = Gundestrup }} [[File:Gundestrupkarret F.I.7074b.jpg|thumb|Another view; exterior plates '''d, e, c, f''']] [[File:Gundestrup cauldron.jpg|thumb|Another view; from left, exterior plates '''b, f, a''']]
The '''Gundestrup cauldron''' is a richly decorated [[silversmithery|silver vessel]], thought to date from between 200 BC and 300 AD,<ref name="Nielsen">Nielsen, S; Andersen, J; Baker, J; Christensen, C; Glastrup, J; et al. (2005). “The Gundestrup cauldron: New scientific and technical investigations”, ''Acta Archaeologica, 76'': 1-58. {{ISSN|0065-101X}}</ref><ref name="Jouttijarvi">Jouttijärvi, Arne (2009), “The Gundestrup Cauldron: Metallurgy and Manufacturing Techniques”, ''Materials and Manufacturing Processes, 24'': 960-966. {{ISSN|1042-6914}}</ref> or more narrowly between 150 BC and 1 BC.<ref>NMD, "The dating and origin of the silver cauldron"; Koch</ref> This places it within the late [[La Tène culture|La Tène]] period or early [[Roman Iron Age]]. The [[cauldron]] is the largest known example of [[European Iron Age]] silver work (diameter: {{convert|69|cm|in|abbr=on}}; height: {{convert|42|cm|in|abbr=on}}). It was found dismantled, with the other pieces stacked inside the base, in 1891 in a [[peat bog]] near the hamlet of Gundestrup in the [[Aars]] parish of [[Himmerland]], [[Denmark]] ({{coord|56|49|N|9|33|E|}}).<ref name="BergquistTaylor">Bergquist, A K & Taylor, T F (1987), “The origin of the Gundestrup cauldron”, ''Antiquity 61'': 10-24.</ref><ref name="Taylor">Taylor, Timothy (1992), “The Gundestrup cauldron”, ''Scientific American, 266'': 84-89. {{ISSN|0036-8733}}</ref><ref name="Olmsted">Olmsted, Garrett S (1979), “The Gundestrup cauldron : its archaeological context, the style and iconography of its portrayed motifs and their narration of a Gaulish version of Táin Bó Cúailnge”, ''Collection Latomus 162'' [Latomus: Bruxelle 1979]. {{ISBN|2-87031-102-8}}</ref> It is now usually on display in the [[National Museum of Denmark]] in [[Copenhagen]], with replicas at other museums; during 2015-16 it was in the UK on a travelling exhibition called ''The Celts''.<ref>[http://www.nms.ac.uk/national-museum-of-scotland/whats-on/celts/ Exhibition page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112064611/http://www.nms.ac.uk/national-museum-of-scotland/whats-on/celts |date=2016-01-12 }}, [[National Museum of Scotland]], 10 Mar - 25 Sep 2016</ref>
The cauldron is not complete, and now consists of a rounded cup-shaped bottom making up the lower part of the cauldron, usually called the base plate, above which are five interior plates and seven exterior ones; a missing eighth exterior plate would be needed to encircle the cauldron, and only two sections of a rounded rim at the top of the cauldron survive. The base plate is mostly smooth and undecorated inside and out, apart from a decorated round medallion in the centre of the interior. All the other plates are heavily decorated with [[repoussé]] work, hammered from beneath to push out the silver. Other techniques were used to add detail, and there is extensive [[gilding]] and some use of [[inlay|inlaid]] pieces of glass for the eyes of figures. Other pieces of fittings were found. Altogether the weight is just under 9 kilograms.<ref>Koch; NMD</ref>
Despite the fact that the vessel was found in Denmark, it was probably not made there or nearby; it includes elements of [[Gaul]]ish and [[Thrace|Thracian]] origin in the workmanship, [[metallurgy]], and imagery. The techniques and elements of the style of the panels relate closely to other Thracian silver, while much of the depiction, in particular of the human figures, relates to the [[Celts]], though attempts to relate the scenes closely to [[Celtic mythology]] remain controversial. Other aspects of the [[iconography]] derive from the [[Near East]].<ref>NMD; Green, 45, Sandars, 255</ref>
Hospitality on a large scale was probably an obligation for Celtic elites, and although cauldrons were therefore an important item of prestige metalwork, they are usually much plainer and smaller than this. This is an exceptionally large and elaborate object with no close parallel, except a large fragment from a bronze cauldron also found in Denmark, at [[Rynkeby]];<ref>Sandars, 252; Megaws, 174-175; Laings, 85, and 68-69 on the even larger, but very fragmentary, Brå cauldron</ref> however the exceptional [[wetland deposits in Scandinavia]] have produced a number of objects of types that were probably once common but where other examples have not survived. It has been much discussed by scholars, and represents a fascinatingly complex demonstration of the many cross-currents in European art, as well as an unusual degree of narrative for [[Celtic art]],<ref>Green, 84</ref> though we are unlikely ever to fully understand its original meanings.
==Discovery== [[File:ChaudronDeGundestrup6.jpg|thumb|The central medallion of the base plate, from a replica]] The Gundestrup cauldron was discovered by peat cutters in a small peat bog called Rævemose (near the larger [[Borremose]] bog) on 28 May 1891.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA396&lpg=PA396&dq=Iconography+of+cernunnos&source=bl&ots=p1RDghDrVJ&sig=fwnvbv0_tjE5JR3O_T585-CZ5E8&hl=fr&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=Gundestrup%20cauldron&f=false|title=Celtic culture: a historical encyclopedia. Vol. 1-|last=Koch|first=John T.|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781851094400|language=en}}</ref> The Danish government paid a large reward to the finders, who subsequently quarreled bitterly amongst themselves over its division.<ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/> Palaeobotanical investigations of the peat bog at the time of the discovery showed that the land had been dry when the cauldron was deposited, and the peat gradually grew over it. The manner of stacking suggested an attempt to make the cauldron inconspicuous and well-hidden.<ref name="BergquistTaylor"/> Another investigation of Rævemose was undertaken in 2002, concluding that the peat bog may have existed when the cauldron was buried.<ref name="Nielsen"/>
The cauldron was found in a dismantled state with five long rectangular plates, seven short plates, one round plate (normally termed the "base plate"), and two fragments of tubing stacked inside the curved base.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/> In addition, there is a piece of iron from a ring originally placed inside the silver tubes along the rim of the cauldron.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/> It is assumed that there is a missing eighth plate because the circumference of the seven outer plates is smaller than the circumference of the five inner plates.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/>
A set of careful full-size replicas have been made. One is in the [[National Museum of Ireland]] in [[Dublin]],<ref>[http://www.museum.ie/en/exhibition/kingship-and-sacrifice.aspx National Museum of Ireland]</ref> and several are in France, including the [[Musée gallo-romain de Fourvière]] at Lyon and the [[National Archaeological Museum (France)|Musée d'archéologie nationale]] at [[Saint-Germain-en-Laye]].
==Reconstruction== Since the cauldron was found in pieces, it had to be reconstructed. The traditional order of the plates was determined by [[Sophus Müller]], the first of many to analyze the cauldron. His logic uses the positions of the trace [[solder]] located at the rim of the bowl. In two cases, a puncture mark penetrating the inner and outer plates also helps to establish the order.<ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/> In its final form, the plates are arranged in an alternation of female-male depictions, assuming the missing eighth plate is of a female.<ref name="Olmsted"/> Not all analysts agree with Müller's ordering, however. Taylor has pointed out that aside from the two cases of puncturing, the order cannot be determined from the solder alignments. His argument is that the plates are not directly adjacent to each other, but are separated by a 2 cm gap; thus, the plates in this order cannot be read with certainty as the true narrative, supposing one exists.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/>
==Metallurgy== [[File:Gundestrupkarret2.jpg|thumb|Inside panel '''A''' with the famous horned figure]] [[File:ChaudronDeGundestrup5.jpg|thumb|Inside panel '''D''' with bull-slaying, replica]] The Gundestrup cauldron is composed almost entirely of silver, but there is also a substantial amount of gold for the gilding, tin for the solder and glass for the figures' eyes. According to experimental evidence, the materials for the vessel were not added at the same time, so the cauldron can be considered as the work of artisans over a span of several hundred years. The quality of the repairs to the cauldron, of which there are many, is inferior to the original craftsmanship.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/>
Silver was not a common material in Celtic art, and certainly not on this scale. Except sometimes for small pieces of jewellery, gold or bronze were more usual for prestige metalwork.<ref>Green, 45</ref> At the time that the Gundestrup cauldron was created, silver was obtained through [[cupellation]] of lead/silver ores.<ref name="Jouttijarvi"/> By comparing the concentration of [[isotope geochemistry|lead isotopes]] with the silverwork of other cultures, it has been suggested that the silver came from multiple ore deposits, mostly from [[Celt]]ic northern [[France]] and western [[Germany]] in the pre-[[Ancient Rome|Roman]] period. The lead isotope studies also indicate that the silver for manufacturing the plates was prepared by repeatedly melting ingots and/or scrap silver. Three to six distinct batches of recycled silver may have been used in making the vessel.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/> Specifically, the circular "base plate" may have originated as a [[phalera (harness)|phalera]], and it is commonly thought to have been positioned in the bottom of the bowl as a late addition, soldered in to repair a hole.<ref name="Taylor"/> By an alternative theory, this phalera was not initially part of the bowl, but instead formed part of the decorations of a wooden cover.<ref name="Taylor"/>
The gold can be sorted into two groups based on purity and separated by the concentration of silver and copper. The less pure [[gilding]], which is thicker, can be considered a later repair, as the thinner, purer inlay adheres better to the silver. The adherence of the overall gold is quite poor. The lack of mercury from the gold analysis suggests that a fire-gilding technique was not used on the Gundestrup cauldron. The gilding appears to have instead been made by mechanical means, which explains the function of closely spaced punch marks on the gilded areas.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/>
An examination of lead isotopes similar to the one used on the silver was employed for the tin. All of the samples of tin soldering are consistent in lead-isotope composition with ingots from [[Cornwall]] in western [[Great Britain|Britain]]. The tin used for soldering the plates and bowl together, as well as the glass eyes, is very uniform in its high purity.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/>
Finally, the glass inlays of the Gundestrup cauldron have been determined through the use of [[X-ray fluorescence|X-ray fluorescence radiation]] to be of a soda-lime type composition. The glass contained elements that can be attributed to calcareous sand and mineral soda, typical of the east coast of the Mediterranean region. The analyses also narrowed down the production time of the glass to between the second century BC and first century AD.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/>
==Flow of raw material== [[File:Detail of Gundestrup Cauldron.jpg|thumb|left|Exterior plate '''d''']] The workflow of the manufacturing process consisted of a few steps that required a great amount of skill. Batches of silver were melted in crucibles with the addition of copper for a subtler alloy. The melted silver was cast into flat ingots and hammered into intermediate plates.<ref name="Nielsen"/> For the relief work, the sheet-silver was annealed to allow shapes to be beaten into high [[repoussé]]; these rough shapes were then filled with pitch from the back to make them firm enough for further detailing with punches and tracers. The pitch was melted out, areas of pattern were gilded, and the eyes of the larger figures were inlaid with glass. The plates were probably worked in a flat form and later bent into curves to solder them together.<ref name="BergquistTaylor"/>
It is generally agreed that the Gundestrup cauldron was the work of multiple silversmiths. Using scanning electron microscopy, Benner Larson has identified 15 different punches used on the plates, falling into three distinct tool sets. No individual plate has marks from more than one of these groups, and this fits with previous attempts at stylistic attribution, which identify at least three different silversmiths.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/><ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/> Multiple artisans would also explain the highly variable purity and thickness of the silver.<ref name="Nielsen"/><ref name="Jouttijarvi"/>
==Origins== [[File:ChaudronDeGundestrup4.jpg|thumb|Interior plate '''B''', replica]] The silverworking techniques used in the cauldron are unknown from the Celtic world, but are consistent with the renowned Thracian sheet-silver tradition. The scenes depicted are not distinctively Thracian, but certain elements of composition, decorative motifs, and illustrated items (such as the shoelaces on the antlered figure) identify it as Thracian work.<ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/>
Taylor and Bergquist have postulated that the Celtic tribe known as the [[Scordisci]] commissioned the cauldron from native Thracian silversmiths. According to classical historians, the Cimbri, a Teutonic tribe, went south from the lower Elbe region and attacked the Scordisci in 118 BC. After withstanding several defeats at the hands of the Romans, the Cimbri retreated north, possibly taking with them this cauldron to settle in Himmerland, where the vessel was found.<ref name="BergquistTaylor"/><ref name="Taylor"/>
Nielsen believes that the question of origin is the wrong one to ask and can produce misleading results. Because of the widespread migration of numerous ethnic groups like the Celts and Teutonic peoples and events like Roman expansion and subsequent Romanization, it is highly unlikely that only one ethnic group was responsible for the development of the Gundestrup cauldron. Instead, the make and art of the cauldron can be thought of as the product of a fusion of cultures, each inspiring and expanding upon one another. In the end, Nielsen concludes that, based on accelerator datings from beeswax found on the back of the plates, the vessel was created within the Roman Iron Age at a location somewhere in Central Europe.<ref name="Nielsen"/>
==Iconography== [[File:Detail 2 from Gundestrupkarret.jpg|thumb|Exterior plate '''f''', with [[torc]]-wearing head]] [[File:Gundestrupkedlen- 00054 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Detail from interior plate '''A''']] [[File:Gundestrup C.jpg|thumb|Interior plate '''C''']]
===Base plate=== The decorated medallion on the circular base plate depicts a bull. Above the back of the bull is a female figure wielding a sword; three dogs are also portrayed, one over the bull's head and another under its hooves. Presumably all of these figures are in combat; the third dog beneath the bull and near its tail seems to be dead, and is only faintly shown in [[engraving]], and the bull may have been brought down. Below the bull is [[Scroll (art)|scrolling]] ivy that draws from classical Greco-Roman art.<ref>Megaws, 175-176; NMD, "The bullfight"</ref> The horns of the bull are missing, but there is a hole right through the head where they were originally fitted; they were perhaps gold. The head of the bull rises entirely clear of the plate, and the medallion is considered the most accomplished part of the cauldron in technical and artistic terms.<ref>Sandars, 256; Laings, 83; Koch</ref>
===Exterior plates=== Each of the seven exterior plates centrally depicts a bust. Plates '''a''', '''b''', '''c''', and '''d''' show bearded male figures, and the remaining three are female.
*On plate '''a''', the bearded man holds in each hand a much smaller figure by the arm. Each of those two reach upward toward a small boar. Under the feet of the figures (on the shoulders of the larger man) are a dog on the left side and a winged horse on the right side. *The figure on plate '''b''' holds in each hand a sea-horse or dragon. *On plate '''c''', a male figure raises his empty fists. On his right shoulder is a man in a "boxing" position, and on his left shoulder, there is a leaping figure with a small horseman underneath. *Plate '''d''' shows a bearded figure holding a stag by the hind quarters in each hand. *The female figure on plate '''e''' is flanked by two smaller male busts. *A female figure holds a bird in her upraised right hand on plate '''f'''. Her left arm is horizontal, supporting a man and a dog lying on its back. Two birds of prey are situated on either side of her head. Her hair is being plaited by a small woman on the right. *On plate '''g''', the female figure has her arms crossed. On her right shoulder, a scene of a man fighting a lion is shown. On her left shoulder is a leaping figure similar to the one on plate '''c'''.
===Interior plates=== *Plate '''A''' shows an antlered male figure seated in a central position, often identified as [[Cernunnos]]. In his right hand, he holds a [[torc]], and with his left hand he grips a horned serpent a little below the head. To the left is a stag with antlers that are very similar to the human/divine figure. Surrounding the scene are other canine, feline, and bovine animals, some but not all facing the human, as well as a human riding a dolphin. Between the antlers of the god is an unknown motif, possibly a plant or a tree.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=QSuYDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT21&lpg=PT21&dq=replicas+of+the+Gundestrup+cauldron+are+found+in+france+and+ireland&source=bl&ots=lEeVG2t0jo&sig=UFd8L8JWX6LejfCJ8QF67NrbA1g&hl=fr&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=replicas%20of%20the%20Gundestrup%20cauldron%20are%20found%20in%20france%20and%20ireland&f=false|title=The Witch's Cauldron: The Craft, Lore & Magick of Ritual Vessels|last=Zakroff|first=Laura Tempest|date=2017-05-08|publisher=Llewellyn Worldwide|isbn=9780738752525|language=en}}</ref> *On plate '''B''', the large bust of a torc-wearing female is flanked by two six-[[spoke]]d wheels, what seem to be two elephants, and two griffins. A feline or hound is underneath the bust. *The large bust of a bearded figure holding on to a broken wheel is at the centre of plate '''C'''. A smaller, leaping figure with a [[horned helmet]] is also holding the rim of the wheel. Under the leaping figure is a horned serpent. The group is surrounded by three [[griffin]]s facing left below, and above, two strange animals who look like [[hyena]]s,<ref>Green, 137</ref> facing right. The wheel's spokes are rendered asymmetrically, but judging from the lower half, the wheel may have had twelve spokes. *Plate '''D''' depicts a bull-slaying scene, with the same composition repeated three times across the plate; the only place where such repetition appears on the cauldron. Three large bulls are arranged in a row, facing right, and each of them is attacked by a man with a sword. A feline and a dog, both running to the left, appear respectively over and below each bull. *On the lower half of plate '''E''', a line of [[warrior]]s bearing spears and shields march to the left with, bringing up the rear a warrior with no shield, a sword, and a boar-crested helmet. Behind him are three [[carnyx]] players. In front of this group a dog leaps up, perhaps holding them back. Behind the dog, at the left side of the scene, a figure over twice the size of the others holds a man upside down, apparently with ease, and apparently is about to immerse him in a barrel or cauldron. On the upper half, warriors on horseback with crested helmets and spears ride away to the right, with at the right a horned serpent, fitted in above the tops of the carnyxes, who is perhaps leading them. The two lines are below and above what appears to be a tree, still in leaf, lying sideways. This is now most often interpreted as a scene where fallen warriors are dipped into a cauldron to be reborn into their next life, or afterlife. This can be paralleled in later [[Welsh literature]].<ref>NMD, "The Gundestrup Cauldron - The Cauldron of Fate?"; Megaws, 176</ref>

==Interpretation and parallels== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Torque à tampons Somme-Suippe Musée Saint-Remi 120208.jpg|[[Bronze]] 4th-century BC buffer-type Celtic [[torc]] from France File:CarnyxDeTintignac2.jpg|Carnyx head from the recently discovered [[Tintignac]] group File:Museum of ScotlandDSCF6355.jpg|[[Torrs Pony-cap and Horns]] File:Celtic Helmet from Satu Mare, Romania.jpg|[[Celts|Celtic]] helmet from [[Satu Mare County|Satu Mare]], [[Romania]] with [[raven]] crest, around 4th century BC File:Letnitsa treasure.png|Thracian plaque with the [[Thracian horseman]] File:Rijksmuseum van Oudheden, schatten uit Limburg, sierschijf van Helden 1.JPG|Thracian disc found in the [[Netherlands]] File:Cylinder Seal, Achaemenid, modern impression 05.jpg|[[Achaemenid]] seal impression with [[Master of Animals]] motif; the Persian king subduing two Mesopotamian [[lamassu]] File:Chalice-crater Louvre CA491.jpg|[[Griffin]] on an [[Pottery of ancient Greece|Ancient Greek vase]] </gallery>
[[File:Shiva Pashupati.jpg|thumb|The [[Pashupati Seal]] ([[Lord of Animals]]) from the [[Indus Valley Civilization]]<ref>{{cite book|title=The Blackwell Companion to Hinduism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SKBxa-MNqA8C&pg=PA204&dq=pashupati+seal+%22Indus+valley+civilization%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jo-HVIDxEpCZyQS8iYDYCQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=pashupati%20seal%20%22Indus%20valley%20civilization%22&f=false|author=Gavin Flood|page=204|publisher=John Wiley & Sons}}</ref> is remarkably similar to the antlered figure of plate '''A'''.<ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Ross">Ross, Ann (1967), “The Horned God in Britain ”, ''Pagan Celtic Britain'': {{ISBN|0-89733-435-3}}</ref>]]
For many years, some scholars have interpreted the cauldron's images in terms of the [[Celtic theology|Celtic]] pantheon, and [[Celtic mythology]] as it is presented in much later literature in [[Celtic languages]] from the [[British Isles]]. Others regard the latter interpretations with great suspicion.<ref>Koch; Megaws, 176</ref> Much less controversially, there are clear parallels between details of the figures and Iron Age Celtic artefacts excavated by archaeology.<ref>Megaws, 174-176; Koch</ref>
Other details of the iconography clearly derive from the art of the [[ancient Near East]], and there are intriguing parallels with ancient India and later [[Hindu]] deities and their stories. Scholars are mostly content to regard the former as motifs borrowed purely for their visual appeal, without carrying over anything much of their original meaning, but despite the distance some have attempted to relate the latter to wider traditions remaining from [[Proto-Indo-European religion]].
===Celtic archaeology=== Among the most specific details that are clearly Celtic are the group of [[carnyx]] players. The carnyx war horn was known from Roman descriptions of the Celts in battle and [[Trajan's Column]], and a few pieces are known from archaeology, their number greatly increased by finds at [[Tintignac]] in France in 2004. [[Diodorus Siculus]] wrote around 60-30 BC (Histories, 5.30): :''"Their trumpets again are of a peculiar barbarian kind; they blow into them and produce a harsh sound which suits the tumult of war''"
Another detail that is easily matched to archaeology is the [[torc]] worn by several figures, clearly of the "buffer" type, a fairly common Celtic artefact found in Western Europe, most often France, from the period the cauldron is thought to have been made.<ref>Megaws, 174-176; Green, 99</ref>
Other details with more tentative Celtic links are the long swords carried by some figures, and the horned and antlered helmets or head-dresses and the [[boar]] crest worn on their helmet by some warriors. These can be related to Celtic artefacts such as a helmet with a [[raptor (bird)|raptor]] crest from [[Romania]], the [[Waterloo Helmet]], [[Torrs Pony-cap and Horns]] and various animal figures including boars, of uncertain function. The shield bosses, spurs and horse harness also relate to Celtic examples.<ref>Megaws, 174-177, 160-163; Green, 100-103</ref> [[File:Taranis Jupiter with wheel and thunderbolt Le Chatelet Gourzon Haute Marne.jpg|thumb|left|[[Gallo-Roman]] figure of [[Taranis]]/[[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] with his wheel and thunderbolt, and carrying torcs]] The antlered figure in plate '''A''' has been commonly identified as [[Cernunnos]], who is named (the only source for the name) on the 1st-century [[Gallo-Roman]] [[Pillar of the Boatmen]], where he is shown as an antlered figure with torcs hanging from his antlers.<ref>Green, 78, 135, 137, 147-148, 151</ref> Possibly the lost portion below his bust showed him seated cross-legged as the figure on the cauldron is. Otherwise there is evidence of a [[horned god]] from several cultures.
The figure holding the broken wheel in plate '''C''' is more tentatively thought to be [[Taranis]], the solar or thunder "wheel-god" named by [[Lucian]] and represented in a number of Iron Age images; there are also many wheels that seem to have been [[amulet]]s.<ref>Green, 147-149</ref>
===Near East and Asia=== The many animals depicted on the cauldron include [[elephant]]s, a [[dolphin]], [[leopard]]-like felines, and various fantastic animals, as well as animals that are widespread across [[Eurasia]], such as snakes, cattle, deer, boars and birds. [[Celtic art]] often includes animals, but not often in fantastic forms with wings and aspects of different animals combined.<ref>Koch; Megaws, 160-163</ref> There are exceptions to this, some when motifs are clearly borrowed, as the boy riding a dolphin is borrowed from Greek art, and others that are more native, like the ram-headed horned snake who appears three times on the cauldron.<ref>Green, 135-139</ref> The art of [[Thrace]] often shows animals, most often powerful and fierce ones, many of which are also very common in the ancient Near East, or the [[Scythian art]] of the [[Eurasian steppe]], whose mobile owners provided a route for the very rapid transmission of motifs and objects between the civilizations of Asia and Europe.
In particular, the two figures standing in profile flanking the large head on exterior plate F, each with a bird with outstretched wings just above their head clearly resemble a common motif in ancient [[Assyrian Empire|Assyrian]] and [[Persian art]], down to the long garments they wear. Here the figure is usually the ruler, and the wings belong to a symbolic representation of a deity protecting him. Other plates show [[griffin]]s borrowed from Ancient Greek art of that of the Near East. On several of the exterior plates the large heads, probably of deities, in the centre of the exterior panels, have small arms and hands, either each grasping an animal or human in a version of the common [[Master of Animals]] motif, or held up empty at the side of the head in a way suggesting inspiration from this motif.
===Celtic mythology=== Apart from Cernunnos and Taranis, discussed above, there is no consensus regarding the other figures, and many scholars reject attempts to tie them in to figures known from much later and geographically distant sources. Some Celticists have explained the elephants depicted on plate '''B''' as a reference to [[Hannibal#Overland journey to Italy|Hannibal's crossing of the Alps]].<ref name="Taylor"/>
Because of the double-headed wolfish monster attacking the two small figures of fallen men on plate '''b''', parallels can be drawn to the Welsh character [[Manawydan]] or the Irish [[Manannán]], a god of the sea and the Otherworld. Another possibility is the Gaulish version of [[Apollo]], who was not only a warrior, but one associated with springs and healing besides.<ref name="Olmsted"/>
Olmsted relates the scenes of the cauldron to those of the [[Táin Bó Cuailnge]], where the antlered figure is [[Cú Chulainn]], the bull of the base plate is [[Donn Cuailnge]], and the female and two males of plate '''e''' are [[Medb]], [[Ailill mac Máta|Ailill]], and [[Fergus mac Róich]]. Olmsted also toys with the idea that the female figure flanked by two birds on plate '''f''' could be Medb with her pets or [[Morrígan]], the Irish war goddess who often changes into a carrion bird.<ref name="Olmsted"/>
Both Olmsted and Taylor agree that the female of plate '''f''' might be [[Rhiannon]] of the [[Mabinogion]]. Rhiannon is famous for her birds, whose songs could "awaken the dead and lull the living to sleep". In this role, Rhiannon could be considered the Goddess of the Otherworld.<ref name="Taylor"/><ref name="Olmsted"/>
Taylor presents a more pancultural view of the cauldron's images; he concludes that the deities and scenes portrayed on the cauldron are not specific to one culture, but many. He compares Rhiannon, whom he thinks is the figure of plate '''f''', with [[Hariti]], an ogress of [[Bactria]]n mythology. In addition, he points to the similarity between the female figure of plate '''B''' and the [[Hindu]] goddess [[Lakshmi]], whose depictions are often accompanied by elephants. Wheel gods are also cross-cultural with deities like Taranis and [[Vishnu]], a god from Hinduism.<ref name="Taylor"/>

{{short description|There is no major conflict between the religious beliefs of Hinduism and acceptance of the science of evolution}} {{Creationism2}} [[Hinduism]] includes a range of viewpoints about the [[origin of life]], [[creationism]] and [[evolution]]. There is no single story of creation, due to dynamic diversity of Hinduism, and these are derived from various sources like [[Vedas]], some from the [[Brahmana]]s, some from [[Puranas]]; some are philosophical, based on concepts, and others are narratives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dailyo.in/variety/hindusim-world-creation-universe-brahma-vishu-shiva/story/1/19522.html|title=How did the world come into being according to Hinduism?}}</ref> The [[Rigveda]] mentions the ''[[Hiranyagarbha]]'' ("golden embryo") as the source of the creation of the Universe, similar to the [[world egg]] motif found in the [[creation myth]]s of many other civilizations. It also contains a myth of [[proto-Indo-European religion|proto-Indo-European]] origin, in which the creation arises out of the [[dismemberment]] of a cosmic being (the [[Purusha]]) who is sacrificed by the gods.<ref name="Jan2007"/> As for the creation of the primordial gods themselves, the [[Nasadiya Sukta]] of Rigveda takes a near-[[agnostic]] stand, stating that the Gods came into being after the world's creation, and nobody knows when the world first came into being.<ref>Griffith, Ralph T.H. (Transl.): [http://www.sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv10129.htm Rigveda Hymn CXXIX. Creation] in Hymns of the Rgveda, Vol. II, 1889-92. Munshiram Manoharlal Publishers Pvt. Ltd., New Delhi, 1999.</ref> In the later [[Puranas|Puranic]] texts, the creator god [[Brahma]] is described as performing the act of 'creation', or more specifically of 'propagating life within the universe'. Some texts consider him equivalent to the Hiranyagarbha or the Purusha, while others state that he arose out of these. Brahma is a part of the [[trimurti|trinity]] of gods that also includes [[Vishnu]] and [[Shiva]], who are responsible for 'preservation' and 'destruction' (of the universe) respectively.
Many Hindu texts mention the [[Hindu cosmology|cycle of creation and destruction]]. The [[Shatapatha Brahmana]] states that the current human generation descends from [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]], the only man who survived a [[flood myth|great deluge]] after being warned by the God. This legend is comparable to the other [[List of flood myths|flood legends]], such as the story of the [[Noah's Ark]] mentioned in the [[Bible]] and the [[Quran]].<ref name="Sunil1999">{{cite book | author=Sunil Sehgal | title=Encyclopaedia of Hinduism: C-G | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zWG64bgtf3sC&pg=PA401 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | year=1999 | publisher=Sarup & Sons | isbn=978-81-7625-064-1 | page=401 }}</ref>
Hindus find support for, or foreshadowing of evolutionary ideas in [[Hindu scriptures|scriptures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.well.com/user/jct/science.html | title=Science and spirituality: Any Points of Contact? The Teachings of U.G.Krishnamurti: A Case Study |last=Moorty | first=J.S.R.L.Narayana| work = Krishnamurti Centennial Conference| accessdate=2008-12-26 |date=May 18–21, 1995|quote=Hinduism has its own version of evolution, which agrees with the scientific theory that evolution is from the simple to the complex and from the homogeneous to the heterogeneous}}</ref> For example, the concept of [[Dashavatara]] can be seen as having some similarities to Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.The [[Matsya|first incarnation of Vishnu]] in the form of a fish resembles the evolutionary origin of fish in the [[Silurian Period]].
In a survey of 909 people, 77% of its respondents in India agreed that enough scientific evidence exists to support [[Darwinism|Charles Darwin’s Theory of Evolution]], and 85% of God-believing people said they agree with evolution as well.<ref name="ncse.com">{{cite web|url=http://ncse.com/news/2009/07/opinions-evolution-from-ten-countries-004885|title=Opinions on evolution from ten countries - NCSE|publisher=|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Hamilton">{{cite news| url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/faith/article2100585.ece | title = One in seven Britons believe in creationism over evolution | location=London | work=The Times | first=Fiona | last=Hamilton}}</ref> According to the survey conducted by [[Pew Forum]] in the [[United States]], 80% of Hindus agree that evolution is the best explanation for the origin of human life on earth.<ref name="pewforum.org">[http://pewforum.org/Science-and-Bioethics/Religious-Differences-on-the-Question-of-Evolution.aspx Religious Groups: Opinions of Evolution], [[Pew Forum]] (conducted in 2007, released in 2008)</ref> However, in India, there were minimal references to Darwinism in the 1800s. Elements of Victorian England opposed the idea of Darwinism. Hindus already had present notion of common ancestry between humans and animals. The Hindu dharma believes that the gods have animal features, showing a theory that humans can be reborn again as animals or with their features.<ref name="Gosling 345–347-348–353">{{cite journal|last=Gosling|first=David|title=Darwin and the Hindu Tradition: Does What Goes Around Come Around?|journal=Zygon|date=June 2011|volume=46|issue=2|pages=345–347–348–353|url=http://authenticate.library.duq.edu/login?url=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ebscohost.com%2flogin.aspx%3fdirect%3dtrue%26db%3drfh%26AN%3dATLA0001843790%26site%3dehost-live|accessdate=2014-01-24|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9744.2010.01177.x}}</ref>
== Hindu creationism ==
According to [[Hindu]] [[creationism]] all [[species]] on earth including [[humans]] have "devolved" or come down from a high state of pure [[consciousness]]. Hindu creationists claim that species of [[plants]] and [[animals]] are material forms adopted by pure consciousness which live an endless cycle of births and rebirths.<ref>Science & Religion: A New Introduction, Alister E. McGrath, 2009, p. 140</ref> [[Ronald Numbers]] says that: "Hindu Creationists have insisted on the antiquity of humans, who they believe appeared fully formed as long, perhaps, as trillions of years ago."<ref>The creationists: from scientific creationism to intelligent design, Ronald L. Numbers, 2006, p. 420</ref> Hindu creationism is a form of [[old earth creationism]]. According to Hindu creationists the [[universe]] may even be older than billions of years. These views are based on the [[Vedas]] which depict an extreme antiquity of the universe and history of the [[earth]].<ref>James C. Carper, Thomas C. Hunt, The Praeger Handbook of Religion and Education in the United States: A-L, 2009, p. 167</ref><ref>A history of Indian philosophy, Volume 1, Surendranath Dasgupta, 1992, p. 10</ref>
=== Creation myths ===
Hinduism is a conglomeration of distinct intellectual or philosophical points of view, rather than a rigid common set of beliefs.<ref>{{cite book | title=Alone in Unity: Torments of an Iraqi God-Seeker in North America | first=Faris | last=Georgis | publisher=Dorrance Publishing | year=2010 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vFZrxLjtiI8C&pg=PA62 | page=62 | isbn=1-4349-0951-4}}</ref> As a result, the [[Hindu texts]] do not provide a single canonical account of the creation; they mention a range of theories of the creation of the world, some of which are contradictory.<ref name="Robert1999">{{cite book | author=Robert M. Torrance | title=Encompassing Nature: A Sourcebook | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uc246yZO0qEC&pg=PA121 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 April 1999 | publisher=Counterpoint Press | isbn=978-1-58243-009-6 | pages=121–122}}</ref>
==== Rigveda ====
The [[Purusha Sukta]] of the earliest Hindu text [[Rigveda]] mentions [[Purusha]], primeval cosmic being.<ref name="SNSadasivan2000">{{cite book | author=S. N. Sadasivan | title=A Social History Of India | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Be3PCvzf-BYC&pg=PA227 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2000 | publisher=APH Publishing | isbn=978-81-7648-170-0 | pages=226–227 }}</ref> Purusha is described as all that has ever existed and will ever exist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sacred-texts.com/hin/rigveda/rv10090.htm|title=Rig Veda: Rig-Veda, Book 10: HYMN XC. Puruṣa.|publisher=|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref> This being's body was the origin of four different kinds of people: the [[Brahmin]], the [[Kshatriya|Rajanya]], the [[Vaishya]], and the [[Shudra]].<ref name=Tignor2014>"Worlds Together Worlds Apart", Fourth Edition, Beginnings Through the 15th century, Tignor, 2014, pg. 5</ref> Viraj, variously interpreted as the [[world egg|mundane egg]]<ref name="SNSadasivan2000"/> (see [[Hiranyagarbha]]) or the twofold male-female energy, was born from Purusha, and the Purusha was born again from Viraj. The gods then performed a [[yajna]] with the Purusha, leading to the creation of the other things in the manifested world from his various body parts and his mind. These things included the animals, the Vedas, the [[Varna]]s, the celestial bodies, the air, the sky, the heavens, the earth, the directions, and the Gods [[Indra]] and [[Agni]]. It is likely that this myth has [[proto-Indo-European religion|proto-Indo-European]] origins, as it is similar to other myths found in the Indo-European cultures, in which the creation arises out of the dismemberment of a divine being (cf. [[Ymir]] of the [[Norse mythology]]).<ref name="Jan2007">{{cite book | author=Jan N. Bremmer | title=The Strange World of Human Sacrifice | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tPjVJF8roYC&pg=PA170 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | year=2007 | publisher=Peeters Publishers | isbn=978-90-429-1843-6 | pages=170–}}</ref>
The concept of Purusha is similar to the concept of [[Brahman]] described in the later texts.<ref name="Roshen2011">{{cite book | author=Roshen Dalal | title=Hinduism: An Alphabetical Guide | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DH0vmD8ghdMC&pg=PA318 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=5 October 2011 | publisher=Penguin Books India | isbn=978-0-14-341421-6 | pages=318–319}}</ref>{{rp|318}} As for the creation of the primordial beings (such as the gods who performed the sacrifice of the Purusha), the [[Nasadiya Sukta]] states:<ref name="McNamaraWildman2012">{{cite book|author1=Patrick McNamara|author2=Wesley J. Wildman|title=Science and the World's Religions [3 Volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3MK5u1_7CLYC&pg=PA180|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=19 July 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-38732-6|pages=180–}}</ref>
{{quotation|<poem> Who really knows, and who can swear, How creation came, when or where! Even gods came after creation’s day, Who really knows, who can truly say When and how did creation start? Did He do it? Or did He not? Only He, up there, knows, maybe; Or perhaps, not even He. </poem> |Rig Veda 10.129.1-7 }}
Rigveda (10.121) also mentions the [[Hiranyagarbha]] (literally, golden embryo/womb/[[world egg|egg]]) that existed before the creation. This metaphor has been interpreted differently by the various later texts. The [[Samkhya]] texts state that Purusha and the [[Prakṛti|Prakriti]] made the embryo, from which the world emerged. In another tradition, the creator god [[Brahma]] emerged from the egg and created the world, while in yet another tradition the Brahma himself is the Hiranyagarbha.<ref name="Edward2009">{{cite book | author=Edward Quinn | title=Critical Companion to George Orwell | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hZET2sSUVsgC&pg=PA188 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2009 | publisher=Infobase Publishing | isbn=978-1-4381-0873-5 | page=188 }}</ref> The nature of the Purusha, the creation of the gods and other details of the embryo creation myth have been described variously by the later Hindu texts.
The early hymns of Rigveda also mention [[Tvastar]] as the first born creator of the human world.<ref>"[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/594460?uid=3739448&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=3737720&uid=4&sid=21101565303097 The Creation Myth of the Rig Veda]" by W. Norman Brown. Journal of the American Oriental Society, Vol. 62, No. 2 (Jun., 1942), pp. 85-98.</ref>
Recounting the creation of gods, the Rig Veda does seem to affirm ‘’creatio ex nihilo’’. Rig Veda 10.72 states: {{quotation|<poem> देवानां नु वयं जाना पर वोचाम विपन्यया | उक्थेषुशस्यमानेषु यः पश्यादुत्तरे युगे || बरह्मणस पतिरेता सं कर्मार इवाधमत | देवानाम्पूर्व्ये युगे.असतः सदजायत || देवानां युगे परथमे.असतः सदजायत | तदाशा अन्वजायन्त तदुत्तानपदस परि ||
1. LET US with tuneful skill proclaim these generations of the Gods, That one may see them when these hymns are chanted in a future age. 2 These Brahmaṇaspati produced with blast and smelting, like a Smith, Existence, in an earlier age of Gods, from Non-existence sprang. 3 Existence, in the earliest age of Gods, from Non-existence sprang. Thereafter were the regions born. This sprang from the Productive Power.<ref>Rig Veda 10.72 translation by R.T.H. Griffith (1896)</ref></poem> }}
==== Brahmanas ==== [[File:The fish avatara of Vishnu saves Manu during the great deluge.jpg|thumb|right|The [[matsya|fish avatara]] of [[Vishnu]] saves [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]], the progenitor of the existing human race, during the [[flood myth|great deluge]].]] The [[Shatapatha Brahmana]] mentions a story of creation, in which the [[Prajapati]] performs [[tapas (Sanskrit)|tapas]] to reproduce himself. He releases the waters and enters them in the form of an egg that evolves into [[Brahmanda|the cosmos]].<ref name="WhitePollak2010">{{cite book | author1=Merry I. White | author2=Susan Pollak | title=The Cultural Transition: Human Experience and Social Transformation in the Third World and Japan. Edited by Merry I White, Susan Pollak | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H5Up5YECUX8C&pg=PA183 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=2 November 2010 | publisher=Taylor & Francis | isbn=978-0-415-58826-3 | page=183 }}</ref> The Prajapati emerged from the golden egg, and created the earth, the middle regions and the sky. With further tapas, he created the devas. He also created the [[asura]]s, and the darkness came into the being.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|102–103}} It also contains a story similar to the other [[List of flood myths|great flood stories]]. After the great flood, [[Manu (Hinduism)|Manu]] the only surviving human, offers a sacrifice from which Ida is born. From her, the existing human race comes into the being.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|102–103}}
==== Upanishads ====
The [[Aitareya Upanishad]] (3.4.1) mentions that only the "[[Ātman (Hinduism)|Atman]]" (the Self) existed in the beginning. The Self created the heaven (''Ambhas''), the sky (''Marikis''), the earth (''Mara'') and the underworld (''Ap''). He then formed the Purusha from the water. He also created the speech, the fire, the prana (breath of life), the air and the various senses, the directions, the trees, the mind, the moon and other things.<ref name="MaxMuller2004">{{cite book | author=F. Max Muller | title=The Upanishads, Vol I | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vz6VFU0jK7UC&pg=PA228 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=30 June 2004 | publisher=Kessinger Publishing | isbn=978-1-4191-8641-7 | pages=228 }}</ref>
The [[Brihadaranyaka Upanishad]] (1.4) mentions that in the beginning, only the Atman existed as the Purusha. Feeling lonely, the Purusha divided itself into two parts: male ("pati") and female ("patni"). The men were born when the male embraced the female. The female thought "how can he embrace me, after having produced me from himself? I shall hide myself." She then became a cow to hide herself, but the male became a bull and embraced her. Thus the cows were born. Similarly, everything that exists in pairs, was created. Next, the Purusha created the fire, the [[soma (drink)|soma]] and the immortal gods (the [[deva (Hinduism)|devas]]) from his better part. He also created the various powers of the gods, the different [[varna in Hinduism|classes]], the [[dharma]] (law or duty) and so on.<ref>[http://sacred-texts.com/hin/sbe15/sbe15055.htm Fourth Brâhmana] in Brihadaranyaka Upanishad, Fourth Brahmana. Translated by Max Müller as The Upanishads, Part 2 (SBE15) [1879].</ref> The [[Taittiriya Upanishad]] states that the being (''sat'') was created from the non-being. The Being later became the ''Atman'' (2.7.1), and then created the worlds (1.1.1).<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} The [[Chandogya Upanishad|Chhandogya]] states that the Brahma creates, sustains and destroys the world.<ref name="ANPrasad2007">{{cite book | author=S.K. Paul, A.N. Prasad | title=Reassessing British Literature: Pt. 1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hpzrfJr-IlEC&pg=PA91 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 November 2007 | publisher=Sarup & Sons | isbn=978-81-7625-764-0 | pages=91 }}</ref>
==== Later texts ==== [[File:An attempt to depict the creative activities of Prajapati.jpg|thumb|350px|left|An attempt to depict the creative activities of Prajapati; a steel engraving from the 1850s]] Belief in evolution is among the [[Samkhya]] philosophy. In the [[Samkhya]] philosophy, evolution is symbolized by the Sanskrit term parinama. Many Hindu reformers compare this term and philosophy with Darwinism. The prominent Vivekananda, based most of his cosmological and biological ideas off of the [[Samkhya]].<ref name="Gosling 345–347-348–353"/> The [[Samkhya]] texts state that there are two distinct fundamental eternal entities: the Purusha and the [[Prakriti]]. The Prakriti has three [[guṇa|qualities]]: ''[[sattva]]'' (purity or preservation), ''[[rajas]]'' (creation) and ''[[tamas (philosophy)|tamas]]'' (darkness or destruction). When the equilibrium between these qualities gets broken, the act of creation starts. ''Rajas'' quality leads to creation.<ref name="Joshi2005">{{cite book | author=Dinkar Joshi | title=Glimpses Of Indian Culture | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-fw-0iBvmMAC&pg=PA32 | accessdate=15 December 2012 | date=1 January 2005 | publisher=Star Publications | isbn=978-81-7650-190-3 | page=32 }}</ref>
The later texts such as the [[Puranas]] identify the Purusha with the [[God in Hinduism|God]]. In many Puranic notes, [[Brahma]] is the creator god.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} However, some Puranas also identify Vishnu, Shiva or Devi as the creator.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}}
In [[Garuda Purana]], there was nothing in the universe except the [[Brahman]]. The universe became an expanse of water, and in that Vishnu was born in the golden egg. He created Brahma with four faces. Brahma then created the devas, asuras, pitris and manushas. He also created the rakshasas, yakshas, gandharvas. Other creatures came from the various parts of his body (e.g. snakes from his hair, sheep from his chest, goats from his mouth, cows from his stomach, others from feet). His body hair became the herbs. The four varnas came from his body parts and the four Vedas from his mouths. He created several sons from his mind, Daksha, Daksha's wife, Manu Svaymbhuva, his wife Shatarupta and the rishi Kashypa. Kashypata married thirrteen of Daksha's daughter and all the devas and the createures were born through them.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|103}} Other Puranas and the Manu Smriti mention several variations of this theory.
In [[Vishnu Purana]], the Purusha is same as the creator deity [[Brahma]], and is a part of [[Vishnu]].<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|319}} The [[Shaivism|Shaivite]] texts mention the Hiranyagarbha as a creation of [[Shiva]].<ref name="Edward2009"/> According to the [[Devi-Bhagavata Purana]] Purusha and Prakriti emerged together and formed the [[Brahman]], the supreme universal spirit that is the origin and support of the universe.<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|319}}
The Advaita Vedanta states that the creation arises from Brahman, but it is illusory and has no reality. (Vivarta)<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{realmente p|103}}
===Hindu cosmological view===
Many Hindu philosophies mention that the [[Hindu cycle of the universe|creation is cyclic]].<ref name="Roshen2011"/>{{rp|104}} According to the [[Upanishad]]s, the universe and the Earth, along with humans and other creatures, undergo repeated cycles (''[[pralaya]]'') of creation and destruction. A variety of myths exist regarding the specifics of the process, but in general the Hindu view of the cosmos is as eternal and cyclic. The later puranic view also asserts that the universe is created, destroyed, and re-created in an eternally repetitive series of cycles. In Hindu cosmology, a universe endures for about 4,320,000,000 years (one [[day of Brahma]], the creator or ''kalpa'')<ref>A survey of Hinduism, [[Klaus K. Klostermaier]], 2007, pp. 495-496</ref> and is then destroyed by fire or water elements. At this point, Brahma rests for one night, just as long as the day. This process, called ''pralaya'' (cataclysm), repeats for 100 Brahma years (311 trillion, 40 billion human years) that represents Brahma's lifespan.
== Modern Interpretations of Scriptural archetypes ==
Most Hindus accept the theory of biological evolution.<ref name="ncse.com"/><ref name="Hamilton"/><ref name="pewforum.org"/> They either regard the scriptural creation theories as allegories and metaphors, or reconcile these legends with the modern theory of evolution.
===Dashavatara=== {{main|Dashavatara#Evolutionary interpretation}}
The order of the [[Dashavatara]] (ten principal [[avatar]]s of the god [[Vishnu]]) is interpreted to convey Darwin's evolution.<ref name="Chandra1998">{{cite book|author=Suresh Chandra|title=Encyclopaedia of Hindu Gods and Goddesses|year=1998|publisher=Sarup & Sons|isbn=978-81-7625-039-9|pages=298}}</ref><ref name="Krishna2010">{{cite book|author=Nanditha Krishna|title=Sacred Animals of India|publisher=Penguin Books India|isbn=978-0-14-306619-4|page=7}}</ref> British geneticist and evolutionary biologist [[J. B. S. Haldane]] opined that they are a true sequential depiction of the great unfolding of evolution. Like the evolutionary process itself, the first avatar of God is a fish - [[Matsya]], then comes the aquatic reptile turtle, [[Kurma]], then a mammal - the boar [[Varaha]], then [[Narasimha]], a man-lion being, [[Vamana]], the dwarf then the rest four are humans; Kalki is not yet born.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Cover Story: Haldane: Life Of A Prodigious Mind | journal=[[Science Reporter]] | year=1992 | volume=29 | pages=46 |publisher=Council of Scientific & Industrial Research}}</ref> Various thinkers and authors like [[Helena Blavatsky]], [[Monier Monier-Williams]], [[Nabinchandra Sen]], [[C. D. Deshmukh]] have associated the Dashavatara with evolution.
===Vanara=== [[File:Building of Rama's Bridge.jpg|thumb|right|The Hindu epics mention an ape-like humanoid species called the [[vanara]]s.]]
The [[Sanskrit]] epics of the Hindus mention several [[exotic tribes of ancient India|exotic creatures]] including ape-like humanoids.<ref>J. K. Trikha, A study of the Ramayana of Valmiki, Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, 1981</ref> Some Hindus see this as a proof of the historicity of their mythological characters and as support for the theory of evolution in their texts. The [[Ramayana]] speaks of the [[Vanaras]], an ape-like species with human intelligence, that existed millions of years ago. According to the Ramayana alongside these [[ape-men]] existed [[modern humans]]. Thus, according to these ancient writings, the status of such creatures was a state of coexistence rather than evolution.<ref>{{cite book|title=A Tribute to Hinduism: Thoughts and Wisdom Spanning Continents and Time about India and Her Culture|page=386|first=Sushama|last=Londhe|year=2008|quote= For example, the Ramayana speaks of the Vanaras, a species of apelike men that existed millions of years ago.|publisher=Pragun Publications}}</ref>
==Hindu opposition to Christian creationism== While the [[Creation–evolution controversy]] has seen much debate in the US and other countries, it is an insignificant issue in India, because of its Hindu-majority population.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Balaram|first = P|title = Editorial| journal = [[Current Science]] | volume = 86| issue = 9| year = 2004| url = http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/may102004/1191.pdf| pages = 1191–1192}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last =Coleman |first = Simon |author2=Carlin, Leslie |title = The Cultures of Creationism: Anti-evolutionism in English-speaking Countries |chapter = The cultures of creationism: Shifting boundaries of belief, knowledge and nationhood |publisher = Ashgate Publishing| page = 3| year = 2003|isbn = 0-7546-0912-X}}</ref> Hindus are among many faiths that have expressed apprehension about efforts to teach [[Christian]] creationism in public schools in the US.<ref>''"Christian agenda worries other faiths: push for intelligent design seen by some as imposing Christianity on others"'', Jim Baker, Lawrence World – Journal, May 12, 2005. See [http://www2.ljworld.com/news/2005/may/12/christian_agenda_worries article on LJ world]</ref> One objection to the teaching of creationism based on the religious texts of a particular faith is that in a pluralistic society this can result in the imposition of one religion.<ref>{{cite web| title = The debate over evolution in Kansas public schools| url = http://www.pluralism.org/research/reports/white/|last = White| first = Aaron| publisher = The Pluralism Project at Harvard University| accessdate = 2008-12-26}}</ref>
